pr_title: 1308 fixed IterableOf.equals and add required tests

timeline.message: fixed IterableOf.equals and add required tests

timeline.bodyText: @lxpdd even though this seems technically correct (judging by the test), this is not well readable and maintainable. I propose to add a todo here to transform this code in something more object oriented. I'm not sure how though, but there must be more declarative solutions that that.
timeline.author: victornoel

replies.bodyText:
@victornoel True, I have another solution with Matched object, but I am not sure if it's correct.
Could I create one more PR for the same issue?
replies.author: lxpdd

replies.bodyText:
@lxpdd you can simply modify this one I think. If you desire so, you can close this PR and open a new one, but there is no need IMHO.
Also can you edit your comment to specify who you are addressing in your comment as per Zerocracy policy: http://www.zerocracy.com/policy.html#42
replies.author: victornoel

timeline.message:
- Fixed Matched class
- Changed IterableOf.equals style for more declarative.

timeline.bodyText: @lxpdd in that case let's use ScalarWithFallback instead of Checked so that we don't have to handle the exception catching.
timeline.author: victornoel

replies.bodyText: @victornoel Thanks. That's what I've been looking for
replies.author: lxpdd

timeline.message: Use ScalarWithFallback object instead of try-catch operations

timeline.bodyText: @lxpdd I think you can use directly true and false, no need to go through an extra layer of indirection
timeline.author: victornoel
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -154,12 +159,20 @@ public boolean equals(final Object other) {
                     () -> other != null,
                     () -> Iterable.class.isAssignableFrom(other.getClass()),
                     () -> {
-                        final Iterable<?> compared = (Iterable<?>) other;
-                        final Iterator<?> iterator = compared.iterator();
-                        return new Unchecked<>(
+                        final Iterable<X> compared = (Iterable<X>) other;
+                        return new ScalarWithFallback<>(
                             new And(
-                                (X input) -> input.equals(iterator.next()),
-                                this
+                                (X value) -> new True().value(),
+                                new Matched<>(
+                                    this,
+                                    compared
+                                )
+                            ),
+                            new IterableOf<>(
+                                new FallbackFrom<>(
+                                    IllegalStateException.class,
+                                    ex -> new False().value()

replies.bodyText: @victornoel Yes, I missed that comment. I will fix it.
replies.author: lxpdd

timeline.bodyText: @lxpdd sorry, I just realized there is something strange here, I don't see how that would implement equals, can you add 2 tests of equals for iterables of equal length : one when the two iterables are equals, and one when they are not?
timeline.author: victornoel

replies.bodyText:
@victornoel
There is two tests that cover it:
notEqualsToIterableWithDifferentElements comparing iterables (1, 2) and (1,0) and
isEqualToIterableWithTheSameElements comparing iterables (1,2) and (1,2)
replies.author: lxpdd

replies.bodyText: @lxpdd ok, thanks, I re-read the code from Matched and now I understand the logical mistake I made, all is good :) thx!
replies.author: victornoel
